Legal_Issue: Did the Appeal Board err in failing to place Rosemary Haney on the eligibility list after finding her qualified?
Evidence_Assessment: Eligibility list expiration, pass mark validity, candidate qualifications
Decision_Outcome: Appeal Board decision set aside
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate error in selection process
Credibility_Factor: Perceived bias and procedural irregularities in selection process
Legal_Rule: Commission must select highest-ranking qualified candidates for eligibility lists under s. 17(1)
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural errors, improper application of pass mark, failure to update eligibility list
Outcome_on_Merits: Appeal Board erred in narrow interpretation of jurisdiction
Key_Evidence_Considered: Revised pass mark rendering Haney qualified, expired eligibility list
Legal_Framework: Public Service Employment Act, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Appeal Board cited expired list and limited jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, correction of eligibility list
Outcome: Judicial review granted, case remanded to new Appeal Board
Legal_Provision: s. 17(1) of the Public Service Employment Act
Authority: Federal Court or equivalent reviewing tribunal

Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Public Service Appeal Board Decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the second selection process was a new process or a corrective measure; whether the Commission had authority to conduct a new selection process
Governing_Law: Public Service Employment Act (PSEA), subsections 21(2), 21(3), and section 10
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review following dismissal of appeal by the Public Service Appeal Board
Evidence_Assessment: Commission's letter stating the nature of the new competition
Decision_Outcome: Appeal Board's decision upheld; judicial review application dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate error by the Appeal Board
Legal_Rule: PSEA allows but does not require corrective measures under subsection 21(3); subsection 21(2) mandates revocation of appointments on successful appeal; merit-based selection under section 10
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by Appeal Board in characterizing the second selection process as entirely new rather than a corrective measure
Key_Evidence_Considered: Commission's letter directing a new competition with updated qualifications
Legal_Framework: Public Service Employment Act (PSEA)
Defendant_Response: Commission acted within its authority under PSEA to direct a new selection process
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Appeal Board decision

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 21(3) and (4) of the Public Service Employment Act
Application_Facts: The applicants attempted to raise new arguments in the third appeal, unrelated to the corrective measures taken following a previous appeal.
Procedural_Issue: Attempt to raise new grounds in subsequent appeal after corrective measures were taken
Jurisdictional_Issue: Appeal Board's jurisdiction limited to issues related to corrective measures under s. 21(3) and (4)
Decision_Outcome: Third Appeal Board's decision upheld
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of Section 21(3) and (4) of the Public Service Employment Act
Decision_Rationale: The Appeal Board correctly interpreted the law; new grounds not permissible under the Act as they were unrelated to corrective measures

Legal_Issue: Whether Section 22 of the Trademarks Act can be used as a ground for opposition in trademark registration proceedings
Procedural_Stage: Judicial Review of Trademarks Opposition Board Decision
Decision_Outcome: Tribunal's decision set aside, matter referred back for reconsideration
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must be satisfied they are entitled to use the trademark under Section 30(i)
Legal_Rule: Section 38(2)(a) allows opposition based on non-compliance with Section 30(i); Section 22 prohibits use of trademarks likely to depreciate goodwill
Standard_of_Review: Error of law and failure to consider relevant jurisprudence
Grounds_for_Claim: Parmalat sought to include Section 22 as a ground for opposing Sysco's 'BLACK DIAMOND' trademark application
Legal_Framework: Sections 22, 30(i), and 38(2)(a) of the Trademarks Act
Defendant_Response: Sysco's response not detailed, but tribunal rejected inclusion of Section 22 as valid ground
Remedy_Requested: Amendment of opposition statement to include Section 22 as ground
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case referred back
Legal_Provision: Section 22, Section 30(i), Section 38(2)(a) of the Trademarks Act
Authority: Trademarks Opposition Board, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Toshie Endo infringe Louis Vuitton's trademarks and pass off counterfeit goods as genuine?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Defendant's admissions, invoices, and evidence of counterfeit goods
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Permanent injunction granted, $30,000 in profits awarded, $12,000 in costs
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff established infringement through defendant's admissions
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Defendant admitted illegal activities during trial
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Trademark infringement occurs when unauthorized use causes confusion or depreciates goodwill
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized sale of counterfeit goods causing consumer confusion
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Admitted importing and selling counterfeit goods
Crimes.Outcome: Permanent injunction, destruction of goods, $30,000 profits, $12,000 costs

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Toshie Endo infringe Louis Vuitton's trademarks and engage in counterfeiting, leading to a breach of commercial honesty?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court analyzed admissions, invoices, and evidence to determine damages
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Permanent injunction, destruction of counterfeit goods, $30,000 profits, $12,000 costs
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff met burden through documentary and testimonial evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Defendant admitted illegal activities during trial
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Trademark infringement occurs when unauthorized use causes confusion or depreciates goodwill
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Importing and selling counterfeit goods violating sections 19 and 20
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Admitted to illegal importation and sale
Crimes.Outcome: Permanent injunction, destruction of goods, $30,000 profits, $12,000 costs

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Toshie Endo infringe Louis Vuitton's trademarks and engage in counterfeiting, leading to a breach of the Trade Marks Act?
Crimes.Outcome: Defendant ordered to pay $30,000 in profits, $12,000 in costs, and cease all related activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Defendant’s admissions deemed credible
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Unauthorized use of registered trademarks on fake goods
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Trademark infringement and counterfeiting under Trade Marks Act
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of identical marks on non-genuine goods
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of fake trademarks on goods

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Toshie Endo infringe Louis Vuitton's trademarks by importing and selling counterfeit products?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Trial confirmed defendant's admissions; court calculated profits and costs
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Permanent injunction, destruction of counterfeit goods, recovery of profits
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Met by plaintiff through direct admissions
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Unauthorized use of registered trademark causing confusion or harm to goodwill constitutes infringement
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Importing and selling goods bearing Louis Vuitton’s registered trademarks without authorization
Crimes.Outcome: Defendant ordered to pay $30,000 in profits and $12,000 in costs; no punitive damages

Dispute_Type: Application to strike a statement of claim
Legal_Issue: Whether a prothonotary has jurisdiction to hear and dispose of an application to strike under Rule 419(a)
Decision_Outcome: Application to strike the statement of claim was dismissed, with costs awarded to the plaintiff
Legal_Rule: Rule 336(1)(g) allows prothonotaries to handle interlocutory applications unless they must be heard by a judge
Outcome_on_Merits: The prothonotary has jurisdiction; the motion to strike was dismissed
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules
Copyright Act
Defendant_Response: Motion to strike the statement of claim
Remedy_Requested: Striking of the statement of claim
Outcome: Dismissal of the application to strike with costs to the plaintiff

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to inadmissibility due to criminality
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Refusal to grant postponement for legal representation
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Not explicitly mentioned, but applicant unable to present evidence effectively
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Deportation order upheld due to criminal conviction
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted of conspiracy to traffic drugs
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Potential risk to public safety due to drug-related offense
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Court transcripts, criminal record, applicant’s testimony
Crimes.Outcome: Initial appeal dismissed; decision set aside on judicial review
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Criminal conviction and failure to demonstrate rehabilitation
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law, principles of natural justice, IRPA
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with correctness for questions of jurisdiction and procedural fairness
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Yes, denial of postponement deprived applicant of fair hearing

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession for the Purpose of Trafficking
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration appeal against deportation based on criminal conviction
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Right to fair hearing and access to counsel in administrative proceedings
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Charter-equivalent fairness principles
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Limited by applicant's inability to present case without counsel
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Deportation order maintained due to conviction
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show eligibility to remain despite criminality
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's limited intellect affecting ability to self-represent
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Right to procedural fairness in administrative hearings
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of natural justice due to lack of legal representation
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Original decision overturned due to procedural unfairness
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal conviction, personal circumstances, request for adjournment
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Requested postponement to secure legal counsel
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of conviction, oral submissions
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Postponement to retain counsel, stay of removal
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, matter remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 64(1) of IRPA (right to appeal), procedural protections under common law
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Appeal Division, Federal Court on review

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration appeal concerning deportation after serious criminal conviction
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA – Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality (section 36)
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Denial of postponement leading to lack of representation
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Evidence available but not effectively challenged
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Public safety concerns associated with drug trafficking
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Criminal court records, sentencing documents, applicant’s statements
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Panel of the Immigration Appeal Division
Crimes.Outcome: Initial decision set aside; case remanded for new hearing
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Yes, refusal to allow time to obtain counsel violated fair hearing rights

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board correctly applied the legal test for state protection
Governing_Law: Requirement of 'adequate protection' by the state, not merely 'serious efforts'
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of safety in Walvis Bay and availability of internal flight alternative
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially rejected based on internal flight alternative
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to demonstrate lack of adequate state protection
Legal_Rule: States must provide 'adequate protection' to citizens
Standard_of_Review: Correctness or reasonableness of legal test application
Grounds_for_Claim: Misapplication of legal test by focusing on 'serious efforts' instead of 'adequate protection'
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conditions in Walvis Bay, possibility of internal relocation
Legal_Framework: Refugee law, principles of state protection, domestic asylum procedures
Evidence_Type: Country condition evidence, legal argument on state protection standards
Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case remitted to differently constituted panel
Authority: Administrative tribunal (the Board), subject to judicial review by court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making False Statements to Immigration Officials
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant changed story from extortion to religious persecution after arrival, provided no corroborative evidence, claimed fear of return to Fujian Province.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Changed reason for fleeing from extortion to religious persecution without supporting evidence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on Fujian Province
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No corroborative evidence for religious persecution claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant's credibility lacking due to inconsistencies and lack of evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed, no question for certification
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Credibility undermined by inconsistent narrative and lack of evidence; country conditions in Fujian not supportive of widespread religious persecution

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility and sur place claim assessment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether RPD erred in assessing credibility and sur place claim
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed, RPD decision upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found inconsistencies between initial claim of extortion and later claim of religious persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of false passport and change in narrative
Crimes.Application_Error: Initial false statement regarding reason for fleeing
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution due to protected grounds
Crimes.Application_Factor: Post-arrival change in basis of claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD’s denial of refugee status upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of fabricated passport to enter Canada

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility of religious persecution claim and RPD assessment of country conditions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether RPD reasonably assessed applicant's claim and country conditions in Fujian
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RPD considered lack of corroborative evidence and conflicting country reports
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD’s decision to deny refugee status upheld
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate well-founded fear of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Change in narrative from extortion to religious persecution
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Convention refugee must face serious risk due to race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Religious persecution in Fujian Province, China
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credible evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CFIA's decision not to revoke appointment and adequacy of alternative remedy
Governing_Law: Public Service Employment Act, staffing principles
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review, appeal, re-determination, second judicial review
Evidence_Assessment: Use of 2006 eligibility list for different position, failure to address lost promotion opportunity
Decision_Outcome: CFIA's decision found unreasonable, set aside by court
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant (Backx) to demonstrate unreasonableness of administrative decision
Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions reviewed on reasonableness standard: justification, transparency, intelligibility
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of staffing principles, inadequate remedy for lost promotion opportunity
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim allowed; decision set aside and referred for re-determination
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of outdated eligibility list, nature of appointment process, lack of meaningful remedy
Legal_Framework: Federal public service staffing regime, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: CFIA allowed grievance but refused to revoke appointment, offered new selection process
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of staffing process, eligibility lists, decision records
Remedy_Requested: Revocation of Griffith's appointment, restoration of fair promotion opportunity
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, matter referred for re-determination by new decision-maker
Legal_Provision: Relevant sections of the Public Service Employment Act and principles of administrative law
Authority: Federal Court, Federal Court of Appeal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Comply with a Recognizance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of continued detention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of immigration detention decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Past gang involvement, credibility issues, unproven allegations
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Crown/Board to justify continued detention
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Board's decision can be overturned if findings unsupported or legal analysis incorrect
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Intermediate standard for mixed fact and law questions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable assessment of danger and alternatives to detention
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Past gang ties, lack of credible bondspersons, rehabilitation efforts
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged detention as unjustified and disproportionate
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, new detention review ordered
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of continued detention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of immigration detention decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Past gang involvement, credibility concerns, unproven allegations
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Board to justify continued detention
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Decision subject to judicial review if findings lack evidentiary support or legal error
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Intermediate standard for mixed fact and law questions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient consideration of current dangerousness and alternatives
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: History of interactions with law enforcement, rehabilitation evidence
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued he was not a current risk and suitable for release
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and release on bail
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, new detention review ordered
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility and detention based on criminality
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Adequacy of consideration of evidence and alternatives
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Evidence considered but not sufficiently weighed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Detention maintained due to perceived danger
Crimes.Review_Mechanism: Judicial review under Federal Court rules
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: History of gang association and related charges
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Danger to the public, criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Link between past conduct and potential future risk
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Board record, police reports, applicant testimony
Crimes.Outcome: Court found decision unreasonable, ordered new hearing
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Perceived ongoing danger and flight risk
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to adequately assess current risk and alternatives

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Insufficient analysis of current danger and alternatives
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Detention extended based on public safety concerns
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged drug trafficking and gang-related activity
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Prior involvement in organized crime and drug offenses
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Connection between past criminal behavior and potential reoffending
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Police records, Board proceedings, applicant statements
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, new detention review ordered
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to meaningfully consider rehabilitation and less restrictive options

Dispute_Type: Administrative law dispute over statutory interpretation and procedural compliance
Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister breached s. 47.1 of the Canadian Wheat Board Act by failing to consult and obtain producer consent before introducing Bill C-18
Governing_Law: Section 47.1 of the Canadian Wheat Board Act
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of legislative intent, text of s. 47.1, and Minister’s actions in introducing Bill C-18 without consultation or vote
Decision_Outcome: Declarations granted that the Minister breached s. 47.1
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants (CWB and producers) to demonstrate statutory breach; met
Credibility_Factor: Minister’s interpretation of s. 47.1 deemed unreasonable by court
Legal_Rule: Section 47.1 requires consultation with CWB and producer consent via vote before introducing legislation that alters marketing mandate or structure
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to consult, failure to obtain producer consent, violation of procedural requirements under statute
Key_Evidence_Considered: Text of s. 47.1, legislative history, absence of consultation records, nature of changes in Bill C-18
Legal_Framework: Statutory interpretation principles, rule of law, administrative law procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Minister argued s. 47.1 applies only to grain inclusion/exclusion, not repeal of the Act
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (legislation, official records), legal argument
Remedy_Requested: Declarations of breach and failure to meet legitimate expectations
Outcome: Declarations granted; Minister found in breach of statutory duty

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
Decision_Outcome: May 5, 1992 decision quashed, effects stayed pending new tribunal
Burden_of_Proof: On appellant to demonstrate procedural unfairness
Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions must adhere to procedural fairness standards, including unbiased tribunal, proper notice, and right to representation
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on context
Grounds_for_Claim: Bias, lack of proper notice, denial of right to representation
Outcome_on_Merits: Procedural unfairness found; decision set aside
Key_Evidence_Considered: Tribunal proceedings, notice documentation, participation records
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, procedural fairness principles
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision, redetermination by new tribunal
Outcome: Decision quashed, stay of effect, new tribunal ordered
Authority: Cowessess Indian Band #73 Appeal Tribunal, judicial review court

Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officer erred in rejecting Ms. Eslamieh's application for permanent residency without considering discretion under subsection 76(3) of IRPA
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to request discretionary consideration
Legal_Rule: Subsection 76(3) of IRPA allows discretion if points do not sufficiently indicate economic establishment, but discretion must be requested by the applicant
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by Visa Officer in not applying discretion under subsection 76(3)
Outcome_on_Merits: Visa Officer’s decision was reasonable and within legal standards
Key_Evidence_Considered: Ms. Eslamieh scored one point below the threshold and did not request discretionary consideration
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Defendant_Response: No obligation to apply discretion unsolicited
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Visa Officer's decision
Outcome: Court dismissed the application, upholding the Visa Officer's decision

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Mahjoub's release can be modified to neutralize threat to national security or safety of any person
Crimes.Outcome: Ordered release under strict conditions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Mahjoub has repeatedly disavowed Islamic extremism; no evidence of contact with terrorists since 2000
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Security certificate alleging ties to terrorist organizations
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Length of detention, compliance with conditions, lack of new evidence, health deterioration
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Whether release under conditions would be injurious to national security or endanger any person
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Ministers' claims without new supporting evidence
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation in obtaining travel documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Engaging in conduct contrary to a court order
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Detention review and modification of release conditions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can Mr. Mahjoub be released under less stringent conditions without posing a threat?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: No new threat-related activities; health issues and isolation noted
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Minister to justify continued detention
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Compliance with prior conditions and willingness to accept GPS monitoring
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for less restrictive conditions due to prolonged detention and health concerns
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Agreed to GPS and modified supervision
Crimes.Outcome: Approved with restrictions

Crimes.Crime_Name: Threatening the security of Canada through association with terrorist groups
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged ties to Egyptian Islamic terrorist organizations
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat to national security if released without controls
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Diminished over time due to long detention and disengagement
Crimes.Organization_Involved: Egyptian Islamic Jihad or related entities
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Alleged involvement based on security certificate
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Classified evidence presented by CSIS; no recent corroboration
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of updated intelligence to support ongoing high threat level
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible past concern but diminished current risk

Crimes.Crime_Name: Participating in activities of a terrorist group
Crimes.Application_Facts: Security certificate issued based on alleged participation
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to immigration control due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Use of security certificate and access to evidence
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over immigration and security
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of recent evidence demonstrating active participation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Past allegations not currently substantiated
Crimes.Outcome: Conditional release ordered
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Threat reduced over time; conditions can mitigate residual risk
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Detention under security certificate for alleged terrorist links
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential danger if released without safeguards
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Reduced due to prolonged detention and behavioral compliance
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Alleged based on intelligence, not criminal conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Based on classified intelligence; limited disclosure
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliance on stale intelligence without renewal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns mitigated by time and behavior
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable belief based on balance of probabilities

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a weapon or explosive substance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can conditions be adjusted to allow less restrictive supervision without compromising security?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of weapon possession; focus on general threat level
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Crown/Minister to justify continued strict detention
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Health deterioration, social isolation, lack of live-in supervisor
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Willingness to accept GPS and restricted movement
Crimes.Outcome: Granted with specific restrictions

Dispute_Type: Procedural fairness in human rights tribunal proceedings
Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant can obtain an interlocutory injunction to halt tribunal proceedings pending judicial review
Governing_Law: Section 18.2 of the Federal Court Act
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application; motion for interlocutory injunction
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to utilize opportunities provided by the Commission to submit new evidence
Decision_Outcome: Motion for stay dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must prove: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience
Legal_Rule: Interim order under s. 18.2 requires: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience favoring applicant
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness due to lack of opportunity to present new evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; injunction denied on procedural grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Opportunities provided by the Commission for evidence submission
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Tribunal process; Federal Court judicial review powers
Remedy_Requested: Interlocutory injunction to pause tribunal proceedings
Outcome: Injunction denied; tribunal proceedings allowed to continue

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in finding residency compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal allowed, citizenship decision quashed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent's credibility questioned due to inconsistent statements
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation in application affecting residency claim
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent reporting of absences and potential misrepresentation
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under s. 14(5) of the Citizenship Act and s. 21 of the Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose all absences from Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Discrepancies in absence reporting and passport evidence not adequately addressed
Crimes.Application_Factor: Accuracy and completeness of residency information

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent met the 1095-day physical presence requirement
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Appeal under s. 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conflicting evidence on absences and passport indicating unreported travel
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove physical presence for 1095 days
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent reporting affecting reliability of claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicant must demonstrate compliance with residency requirement
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory residency requirement
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Citizenship Act and Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal allowed; respondent may reapply

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose change in marital status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant applied for permanent residency before marriage, married before landing, and did not inform immigration authorities.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with disclosure requirements during application process
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to disclose change in marital status constitutes misrepresentation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Disclosure required during entire application process including pre-landing phase
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of IAD decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Application forms, marriage certificate, correspondence with IRCC
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of notification of marriage prior to landing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly challenged, but non-disclosure undermined procedural compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Wife excluded from family class; sponsorship refused
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturning of IAD's refusal of spousal sponsorship
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: 'Time of that application' includes period up to granting of permanent residence; failure to disclose marriage precludes inclusion under family class

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interpretation and application of s. 117(9)(d) of IRPR
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of IAD appeal dismissal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Marriage occurred after PR application but before landing; no examination conducted
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility and compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: No allegation of fraud, but procedural non-compliance found
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Non-accompanying family members not examined during principal applicant’s process are excluded from family class
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Spouse should be considered family class member despite non-disclosure
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timeline of application, marriage date, landing date, lack of disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Family class sponsorship under IRPA and IRPR
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Regulation validly applied; no error in interpretation
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Inclusion of spouse in family class and approval of sponsorship
Crimes.Outcome: Sponsorship refused due to regulatory exclusion

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether s. 117(9)(d) violates Charter s. 7 rights
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms s. 7; IRPR s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review stage with constitutional argument
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant had no legal right to enter Canada prior to permanent residency
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove infringement of Charter rights
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not applicable – issue of law, not credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: No breach of s. 7 where regulation applies to foreign nationals outside Canada without status

Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over damages for sale of counterfeit goods
Legal_Issue: Should damages for selling counterfeit goods be assessed individually or jointly and severally among defendants?
Procedural_Stage: Default judgment stage due to defendants' failure to respond
Evidence_Assessment: Defendants admitted involvement by not defending; difficulty in distinguishing individual contributions to the infringement
Decision_Outcome: Joint and several liability imposed on all defendants
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs established liability through default and legal framework
Credibility_Factor: Defendants did not contest the claims, implying admission of facts
Legal_Rule: Joint and several liability applies under the Copyright Act; solidary liability under Quebec's Civil Code when multiple parties contribute to a wrongful act
Standard_of_Review: Assessment based on statutory interpretation and civil liability principles
Grounds_for_Claim: Sale of counterfeit goods by multiple defendants at a fixed retail location
Outcome_on_Merits: Liability established on merits through default and application of law
Key_Evidence_Considered: Involvement in distribution of counterfeit goods
Legal_Framework: Statutory framework of the Copyright Act and Quebec Civil Code provisions on solidary obligations
Outcome: Judgment issued against defendants jointly and severally for $6,000
Legal_Provision: Quebec Civil Code articles on solidary liability

Prior_Criminality: convicted of assault and illegal firearm possession
Sentencing_Issue: sentenced to 24 months imprisonment and probation

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining that Mr. Nava Flores' firearm offense constituted a 'serious non-political crime' under Article 1F(b) of the Convention
Evidence_Assessment: considered the maximum penalty (10 years), ongoing threats, and potential use of the firearm as aggravating factors
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed
Legal_Rule: individuals who have committed serious non-political crimes abroad are excluded from refugee protection
Grounds_for_Claim: prior conviction for illegal firearm possession
Legal_Framework: Article 1F(b) of the Convention
IRPA

Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration requirements
Legal_Issue: Did the Immigration Officer improperly fetter her discretion or breach the duty of fairness in refusing to exempt the applicant from visa requirements?
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; no grounds for certiorari order
Legal_Rule: Under s. 114(2) of the Immigration Act, exemptions can be granted for public policy or humanitarian and compassionate reasons. Discretion cannot be unreasonably restricted.
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper application of guidelines, exclusion from Illegal De Facto Resident Policy
Outcome_on_Merits: No improper fettering of discretion or breach of fairness found
Legal_Framework: s. 114(2), Immigration Act; Illegal De Facto Resident Policy

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer's decision to deny exemption from visa requirements based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds or public policy was lawful
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant sought permanent residency exemption under humanitarian grounds but was denied due to ineligibility under relevant policies
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Prior immigration attention leading to ineligibility under Illegal De Facto Resident Policy
Legal_Standard: Lawfulness, fairness, and reasonableness of administrative decision-making
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; no grounds for overturning decision

Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and sought permanent residency under humanitarian grounds
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to overstay and invalid status
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; no grounds for certiorari order
Relief_Sought: Permanent residency exemption under humanitarian grounds
Legal_Standard_Applied: Fairness and reasonableness in administrative discretion
Decision_Rationale: Guidelines followed; no unreasonable fettering of discretion
